div.p: HAVE FEATURES one NEEDS in SELF:oneself FOR ACHIEVING something.
1. The commonest word is néng 能 "have an inherent capacity for, have the personal ability to".
2. Kě yǐ 可以 "be in an objective position to, have the possibility to".
3. Zú yǐ 足以 emphasises sufficiency of conditions necessary to get something done.
4. Kè 克 typically comes to emphasise the ability to do something difficult in post-archaic times, but the word was equivalent to néng 能 in early texts.
5. Rén 任 emphasises a general qualification to achieve something worth achieving and not obviously easy to achieve.
6. Kān 堪 typically refers to the ability to do something others might not be willing or psychologically able to do.
7. Jì 技 "expertise, know-how" refers to the talents for crafts and the like, and the word is not normally used as a verb. See SKILL.
8. Lì 力 "strength" is sometimes used to refer to an ability to do something which in some sense requires strength.
9. Zhī 知 refers to the intellectual ability to do something, especially to do something that is not intellectually trivial.
10. Jì néng 技能 refers to a lasting acquired skill.
NB: Dé 得 "cope, show an ability to do something by actually doing it" is an achievement verb and does not belong in this group. See COPE.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: POSSE est vires ad aliqvid habere.
Generalius loqvendo potentia sive facultas ad res agendum triplex est

1. per proprias Vires, et haec est Qvalitas, Pollentia, Robur. 2. per impedimentorum absentiam, et haec est Libertas, Licentia, Jus, Fas, Authoritas, Venia. 3. Per res ipsas commode se offerentes: haec dicitur Occasio, Opportunitas, Commoditas.
posse refers to an ability as a consequence of power or strength.
quire refers to an ability as a conseq uence of a consummate qualification.
valere refers to the possession of the right measure of strenght in order to live up to a certain task or to handle a situation.
pollere refers to the possession of very considerable strength or other means whereby one excels others in the ability to do things or to get one's will.

1. From a semantic point of view what needs to be compared with ne2ng 能 is not only ke3 可 which does differ in obvious ways with regard to passivisation of the verb it governs, but ke3 yi3 可以. It is in the latter contrast that serious misunderstandings are easy to find.

sense.def: =技 entertaining trick, attractive skill [also general: skill in any field

entry.def: Rén 任 emphasises a general qualification to achieve something worth achieving and not obviously easy to achieve. ABSOLUTE, CURRENT, DIFFICULT, ENDOGENIC, ACQUIRED, TEMPORARY, PSYCHOLOGICAL.

sense.def: capability, power; capabilities, abilities; ability to perform duties
be able to undertake, qualify for (a task);; be qualified for (fame);
be undertaken, be taken upon oneself 難任
be able to perform the contextually determinate task

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

entry.def: Kè 克 typically comes to emphasise the ability to do something difficult in post-archaic times, but the word was equivalent to néng 能 in early texts. ABSOLUTE, ARCHAIC, INCIDENTAL, TEMPORARY, PHYSICAL.

sense.def: be capable and efficient
archaic: be capable of V-ing; be able to overcome the task of V-ing, have the stamina and power to; manage the difficult task of V-ing

entry.def: Lì 力 "strength" is sometimes used to refer to an ability to do someting which in some sense requires strength.

sense.def: extent of one's ability, physical capacity

entry.def: Kě 可 is occasionally used for kěyǐ 可以 and typically comes before passivised verbs: "be V-able".

sense.def: can; is able to (short for 可以 with omitted verbal object)
it is possible to V, one can V; it is possible that there be V-ing
transitive verb which takes passivised verbs as object: may probably be VERBed; be VERBable
have the objective possibility of V-ing
transitive verb with omitted passive verbal object: may properly be VERBed; be (VERB)able

entry.def: Kān 堪 typically refers to the ability to do something others might not be willing or psychologically able to do. ABSOLUTE, CURRENT, DIFFICULT, EMOTIONAL, ENDOGENIC, INHERENT, INNATE, LASTING, PSYCHOLOGICAL.

sense.def: be able to undertake the contextually determinate V-ing
be able to undertake; be up to; have the capability to
be able to undertake; be able to play the role of; be up to (a task, an honour); be up to (an opponent)
manage to do the contextually determinate thing V
be amenable to being V-ed (Find some of the many early examples!)
manage to V; be able to V
be able to V (verbal complement expressing capability)
be able to VERB1 to the extent of VERB2 趁得及 糶得盡

entry.def: Jì 技 "expertise, know-how" refers to the talents for crafts and the like, and the word is not normally used as a verb. See SKILL. GRADED, CURRENT, DIFFICULT, ACQUIRED, LASTING, PSYCHOLOGICAL, PRACTICAL.

sense.def: expertise, professional skill
be skillful (especially with one's hands)
be intellectually capable of V-ing
be able to V
have a skill for

entry.def: Zhī 知 refers to the intellectual ability to do something, especially to do something that is not intellectually trivial.

sense.def: be intellectually capable to V; understand how to, know how to V; have the good sense to; know the importance of Ving
be intellectually capable of Nab

entry.def: Nài 耐 refers to a physical ability to do something and appears to be a loan for 能.

sense.def: be able to (loan for 能)

entry.def: The commonest word is néng 能 "have an inherent capacity for, have the personal ability to". CURRENT, ENDOGENIC, GRADED, INHERENT, LASTING

sense.def: capability; physical capability, concrete technical capability; potential, capacity 人各有能
capable, possessed of political clout, skilfull 能人
be able to perform a contexually determinate action or achieve a contextually determinate quality
be capable and competent; be able to act, be in a position to act
be physically able to; have the capacity to VERB properly, be constitutionally able to VERB; be physically capable of, be actually able to; would ever be able to
be competently mastered
(of non-human/inanimate subjects) be able to V
feel able to; be (temporarily) able to
be capable of N (as in 何能"what is he capable of" 能之)
consider as capable
show a capacity for; be capable of Nab-ing
be capable of the contextually determinate thing
men who have qualifications/abilities
his own abilities
be able to V
be able to; know how to
have the ability for
qualified to V
be able to V, have enough ability to carry out the bad V-ing

entry.def: Kě yǐ 可以 "be in an objective position to, have the possibility to". ABSOLUTE, INCIDENTAL, EXOGENIC, TEMPORARY, PHYSICAL.

sense.def: be (thus 以之) in an objective position to, have the (circumstantially determined) possibility to
be able to V
be able to achieve the contextually determinate Ving

entry.def: may be V-ed, one may V them

sense.def: be capable of being V-ed
manage to; can come to

entry.def: Jì néng 技能 refers to a lasting acquired skill.

sense.def: skills and abilities of all kinds; one's skills; skill in general
those who have skills
abilities
get to be able
ability and strength

entry.def: Zú yǐ 足以 emphasises sufficiency of conditions necessary to get something done. GRADED, INHERENT, PHYSICAL

sense.def: be worth V-ing
be capable of V-ing (NOT: be sufficient to V with); be in a position to
be in a state to, can bear to
have what it takes to; be able thereby to
= zhi4néng 智能: intellect and capabilities
= kěyi3 可以: be able to V
be able to undertake, qualify for N
fully competent persons
natural (inborn) capacity
belong to human congenital nature
arcane poetic: be able to
